title: Pocket cruiser
text:
A pocket cruiser is a <a href="sailboat">sailboat</a> designed for recreational <a href="Cruising%20%28maritime%29">cruising</a> and club racing, under in length.
Like the similar and usually smaller <a href="trailer%20sailer">trailer sailer</a> they have design features to make it possible to tow them with passenger vehicles, such as light weight, and short <a href="Sailing%20ballast">ballast</a>ed retractable shoal draft <a href="keel">keel</a>s.
Being cruisers, they also include amenities that provide the comfort of larger boats, such as a <a href="Cabin%20%28ship%29">cabin</a>, with <a href="Berth%20%28sleeping%29">berths</a>, a <a href="Galley%20%28kitchen%29">galley</a>, a <a href="Head%20%28watercraft%29">head</a>, and <a href="Cockpit%20%28sailing%29">cockpit</a>.
Properly equipped, these style boats are capable of long offshore passages, as proven by circumnavigators <a href="Eric%20and%20Susan%20Hiscock">Eric and Susan Hiscock</a>, <a href="Lin%20and%20Larry%20Pardey">Lin and Larry Pardey</a>, and <a href="Tania%20Aebi">Tania Aebi</a>, among others. 
The term was coined in the 1970s as fiberglass sailing <a href="yacht">yacht</a> building took off.
